I went in to Durham, and dedicated the altar which

has set up in the Gallilee to the memory of her husband. There was a goodly company of invited friends, and the little service, though very brief, was also very reverent. I delivered a brief oration, in which
I just alluded to the multiplication of altars in our churches as a practice which called for the careful consideration of the Church

. Personally, I dislike it, and doubt whether it can be safeguarded from misunderstanding and abuse. But it was no suitable occasion for enlarging on a contentious subject which yet I could not ignore.

It is not improbable that his illness may end fatally within the next few weeks. I decided, therefore, that for the present we must await events, & I promised to try and discover some man to do the parochial work. Then I went on to

, & discussed the matter with him. Would the heavens fall if, in this shortage of suitable clergy, I authorized the closing of a parish during the illness of an incumbent, or during the vacancy of a living? A small payment to an adjoining incumbent would secure to the parishioners all that was indispensable, and a short suspension of services in the parish church could hardly inflict any serious or lasting injury on parochial religion. The subject merits my careful consideration.
